comments.content: I live alone and have 25 devices connected to my SOHO router. Think computers, phones, ipad, watches, alexa, fitbits, smart tv's, gamming systems, etc..... Now imagine a home with 6 people in it
I agree makes no sense at all

discussion.content: An average home router has a DHCP scope size of 200 IP addresses. You mean to tell me that a home user has over 200 items connected to the internet in their house? Yeah, I think not. Another irrational and illogical answer.

with these questions, eliminate first, here goes

A. The DHCP scope has been exhausted.
B. The security passcode has been changed - eliminated 
C. The SSID is hidden - eliminated
D. The AP configuration was reset - eliminated

the reason I support A is that all home routers I have come across can have their DHCP scope reduced to a handful of IPs. In my home that number is 10. To make sure my own devices always get an IP, I also add a DHCP reservation for their MAC addresses. 

This behavior of not getting an IP is due to DHCP scope exhaustion.

Selected Answer: A
How many devices do you have in your house!?
I support A, having minimized my DHCP pool to account for wastage and encountering the same problem when devices wouldn't release their lease.
please remember that the ? may have been written in 2007 lol....back then, and even today, a 5 or 10 limit on devices exists
I believe the answer lies in the fact that the Laptop was not connected because he was on vacation, and releases a IP from the DHCP scope.
Yep. But it's definitely the correct answer considering the alternatives. But absolutely not what any tech would consider as the first, second, or 50th likely cause of the issue.

choices.B: The security passcode has been changed.
choices.A: The DHCP scope has been exhausted.

questions.question_text:
A home user has purchased a new smart TV to stream online video services. The smart TV is unable to connect to the wireless network after several attempts.
After returning from vacation, the home user tries again and can connect the TV to the wireless network. However, the user notices a laptop is no longer able to connect to the network. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

discussion.content: After thinking it through, I believe that B. Social engineering is the correct answer. Just as liztorres78 mentioned, it's not considered an insider threat because it doesn't state that the individual is committing a malicious act or is directing an attack from WITHIN the company. Social engineering is defined as fooling or deceiving others into thinking that you are from a company, and that's exactly what this individual is trying to do. So yes, B makes sense, but it helps to re-read the question and understand the different types of threats.

I believe the answer given is the right one. The fact that the individual is "authorized" makes him an insider. However, being an insider, it's possible that there are levels of access, hence the person may not be allowed to enter the lab areas due to privilege descriptions. This is what labels that person as a threat as they're attempting to access secure levels above their jurisdiction.
The answer is C because the question says AUTHORISED user, that's the key word

How do we know a security threat is even taken place? Jumping to major conclusions, It 
could be just authorised worker doing their job
ITs insider threat. the key word is AUTHORIZED. a social engineering threat is not given direct access.
authorized person works in there but he doesn't have access to enter the lab, he did by entering with a group of people so he become an insider threat. answer is correct
Since tailgating is not on the list , I'll go with C) Insider treat

The correct answer is Insider threat simple because it's states "An authorized individual". n authorized individual can do an attack in the organization. No one is being manipulated here, the threat comes from inside or it comes within the organization. So the correct answer is C.

C is absolutely, irrefutably wrong. An insider threat means that the person is already either inside the network or has been employed by the company and is now using their access to be a threat to the company. This is, in fact, an example of social engineering. (albeit a failed attempt because the guy got noticed, but still he tried) He's posing as someone who is supposed to be there, thus using the social aspect of using a doctors disguise to gain access to places he should not have access to.
Wow everyones brain short circuits on the question. It states the person is authorized but happens to be headed to a secure area so its actually a insider threat.

FWIW, Passleader shows the answer as B) Social Eng.
My gut tells me the answer to this question relies entirely on the premise that this person is 'authorized'

comments.content: Well, one of them IS authorized, it says.. and he's letting others in..

discussion.content: cant be insider threat if you are NOT an INSIDER....an insider MUST be an employee....Jesus
Somehow, I think they misspelled "authorized" instead of "unauthorized" which would then make a lot more sense.

"A security guard notices an authorized individual, who is dressed like a lab technician, has entered a secure area of the hospital with a large group. Which of the following security attacks is taking place?" 
"authorized individual"... They're allowed to be there. "a large group"... Doesn't say whether they are or aren't allowed to be there. It also doesn't say whether dressing like a lab technician is or isn't out of the normal or allowed... There's WAY too much missing information! Is the attack the group of people, the authorized person, the fact that they're dressed like a lab tech??? Tell me what the threat is and I'll tell you what kind of attack this is. The exam better be significantly more specific than this!

It's not an insider threat because the individual is "posing" as someone who is credible and convincing. It's obvious that the security guard recognized the person, but knows that the individual doesn't have the required access. IF that individual went unnoticed and carried out some sort of malicious intent, then it would be an insider threat. However, the person was trying to use a disguise in hopes of unwittingly fooling people into thinking that [they] had every right to be there.
i cant understand how this is social engineering.... why not inside treat
in my view, this cannot be social engineering because the individual is authorized personnel who dress like a lab technician heading to a secure area... this answer could be inside threat

comments.content: It is definitely social engineering because the individual has gained access through pretending to be someone which they are not, just like when you obtain someone's account login details by pretending to be a bank personnel.

questions.question_text: A security guard notices an authorized individual, who is dressed like a lab technician, has entered a secure area of the hospital with a large group. Which of the following security attacks is taking place?

discussion.content:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipv6_basic/configuration/xe-3se/5700/ip6-aaaa-dns.html

"PTR

Maps an IPv6 address to a hostname. (Equivalent to a pointer record [PTR] in IPv4.)"
To resolve IPv6 addresses, DNS uses the AAAA record. The AAAA record can store a 128-bit address and can resolve IPv6 addresses.
the correct answer is(C) AAAA address record maps hostname to IPv6 address
The AAAA record is conceptually similar to the A record, but it allows you to specify the IPv6 address of the server, rather than the IPv4

Correct answer is A. PTR.
They ask "IPv6 records to be resolved to DNS names" = IPv6 PTR records.
More information:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rvUEZTLsrgg
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_DNS_lookup
I think the correct answer is PTR. A/AAAA records resolve a FQDN to an IP address, while PTR does the reverse of resolving an IP address to FQDN.

questions.question_text: Which of the following DNS record types allows IPv6 records to be resolved to DNS names?

discussion.content: the two ports 5060 & 5061 both are on UDP/TCP and are both associated SIP by IANA. In particular, port 5060 is assigned to clear text SIP, and port 5061 is assigned to encrypted SIP, also known as SIP-TLS (SIP over a TLS, Transport Layer Security, encrypted channel). Unfortunately, the standard TLS (successor of SSL) can only be established over TCP. Does this mean SIP UDP-based communications have to travel unencrypted? Fortunately not. An IETF draft covering SIP-DTLS is on the queue (DTLS is Datagram TLS, that is, UDP.

Correct answers are:
C. UDP 5060 is allowed.
D. UDP 5061 is allowed.
SIP clients typically use TCP or UDP on port numbers 5060 or 5061 for SIP traffic to servers and other endpoints. Port 5060 is commonly used for non-encrypted signaling traffic whereas port 5061 is typically used for traffic encrypted with Transport Layer Security (TLS).
More information:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Session_Initiation_Protocol
How in the world would UDP 5061 be an answer when UDP, according to my research, does not work on that port?
